description:
This is the game about your city, Kalmar. You buy, sell and trade properties and building plots to win. You will feel at home on the game board, going from Norrliden to Varvsholmen. Cards with pictures and instructions take you from familiar and unfamiliar situations and locations in the historical, contemporary and future Kalmar.

Players assume the role of landlords, purchasing and trading streets, squares and properties. Players landing on the streets and squares of other players must pay rent depending on if the plot is empty or if properties have been built on the plot. The unique plots for the squares Larmtorget, Stortorget, Lilla Torget and Skvallertorget, and for the local newspapers Östran and Barometern, are unbuildable, meaning that the rent is fixed; buying more of the same set garners you more money when players land on those plots.

Players play the game by rolling two dice, adding the sum together and moving on the game board equal to the sum of the dice. Players may only buy properties that are unowned, and it takes owning all streets of an individual color set to be able to build properties on the streets. For example, to be able to build properties on Norrliden, Funkabo must also be owned by you, as it belongs to and completes the orange set. While moving along the board, players may also land on tile which force you to draw cards, whose effects may be both beneficial and disadvantageous.

The goal of this game is, by the roll of the dice and mercantile shrewdness, to be the last player left with money, having forced your competitors into bankruptcy.

—description from the designer

In 1989, El Patrón declared total war against the government of Colombia, as well as the police and the army. He controls more than 80% of drug trafficking worldwide. His personal fortune is estimated between 25 and 30 billion dollars. Those who oppose him and refuse to be bribed are murdered by his men. He is one of the most powerful men in the world, and only the DEA and a small group of incorruptible local agents stand between him and his ultimate goal: to become the President of Colombia.

In Narcos Plata o Plomo one player takes control of El Patrón's empire while the other players have to cooperate to surround and capture him in Medellin before he gets enough influence to achieve his goal. For the law forces it is a race against time: the advance of El Patrón is implacable, so they must gather all their strength and recover control of the city comuna to comuna, cornering him before the elections turn him into the future President of the country and, therefore, untouchable to the forces of law.

—description from the designer

Takayama is a dexterity game to play alone or with unlimited players. The goal is to build the highest mountains by stacking the various pieces of wood, measuring them and summing these measurements to reach 100 cm. The first player to reach 100 cm or more wins.

Each player builds his mountain during turn by turn. The smallest player starts. In front of him, he places the base of the mountain (wooden board) and the tokens with the symbols facing down. He randomly turns a first token, takes the piece of wood with the corresponding symbol and places it on the wooden base. The player has the right to place it on the position he chooses, but only on the edge ! This is the first part of the mountain.
 Next, he turns a second token, places once again the corresponding piece of wood on the previous piece and continues to build his mountain. The player may, at any time, decide to continue or interrupt his construction. If the player is satisfied with his mountain, he stops, measures its height and writes down the score. The next player can start. If, on the other hand, the player continues and his construction collapses, his score will be zero for that round and the turn of the next player begins.

Pathogen is a game about conquering cells. You're in control of a mutating virus spore. Your aim is to multiply your Virus, Infect nearby Cells, and Invade the opposition. It's a battle of the strongest virus.

There are 2 Win Conditions. First Player to control 8 Cells wins the game, or the first player to invade and infect the opponents Home Cell wins the game.

Cells are arranged face down randomly, there are 12 in total, and each cell has Resilience and Energy, as well as a unique ability. Resilience is the health of the cell, and Energy is how much energy it produces once you capture it.

Some cells are controlled by Grey Parasites, they are like a neutral enemy, players must defeat before capturing that cell.

A player has several Active Actions as well as Passive Actions.
Each player can perform 2 Active Actions, but can never Move the same Virus die twice. Once a player controls 3 Cells then he gains 1 additional Active Action.
Passive Actions are situational, and happen at different phases of the game.

Active Actions
Multiply, Split, Move, Invade, Infect, Pass.
Passive Actions
Grow Virus, Collect Energy, Upkeep, Scout, Grow Spore, Draw Mutation Card, Mutate.

Movement is done between Cells in a diagonal fashion.

Players can also earn Mutation Cards 
There are 2 types of Mutations, Active, and Passive. Passive mutations are played face up, and they give you an ongoing bonus. Active mutations are played face down, and are 1 time use mutations. Mutation card can be purchaded, but they are expensive, at 10 energy. Mutation Achievements are as follow.


     Expansion: Draw Mutation Card when you control your third cell.
     Central Advancement: Draw Mutation Card when you control a Central Cell.
     Turtle Power!: Draw Mutation Card when you Grow 5 Spores.
     Exponential Army: Draw Mutation Card when you Have 5 Virus Dice with 6 in one Cell.


The Game is a frantic race to control cells, grow and multiply your virus army, and defeat your opponent.

—description from the designer

VIAE is a strategic and competitive Area-Control Board Game set during the rise of the Roman Empireâ€‹.

As Tribunes, you conquer the world for the glory of Rome. Build roads, smite your enemies and gain influence in the Senate. But watch your back, your fellow Tribunes will aim to disrupt your goals.

In VIAE you build roads, conquer cities and disrupt others to become the first to achieve their goals.

The goal of the game is to be the player with the most influence at the end of the game.
As soon as a player completes two Mandatum, the game ends.
Mandatum give you bonus influence at the end of the game.
You can gain influence in different ways, the most common being conquering cities.
Influence is a resource you can use to play Deceptio cards that manipulate the game state.

—description from the designer

This is solitary, easy and short card driven game for the Battle of Madrid (november-december 1936) of the Spanish Civil War.

There are two types of Cards. Battle Cards with a numerical value from 1 to 7, and Position Cards, which represent historical fortifications.

The player must set up his  battle cards in the gaps before you draw all the fortification cards. when a Positioin card is draw, you can't place any more cards in this gap.

Victory or defeat for the player is when all cards are drawn. If all gaps (12) have a Position card, is a republican Victory, but if there is any gap with 7 or 14-28  Battle cards without Position, there is a Fascist victory.

—user summary

“We’re very afraid to enter! The castle of the Colorsnatching Witch is frightening!
The evil witch had attempted stealing the rainbow before and leaving the world colorless – and she hadn’t managed to... until now!
The Kanyitos are trapped inside the castle, and can’t help humankind anymore. Marahuero, the witch’s cat, helped us get in and told us how to save them. Now it’s too late to turn back. We have only three days to rescue them and get away!”

Kanyimajo is a card game in which you’ll be trying to free the Kanyitos and Kanyikats from the claws of the evil Coloursnatching Witch (Bruja Robacolores).
You’ll have to collect kokeshi-doll amulets, jewels and flowers of many colours to break the witch’s spell, and confide with the Amaterasu and Izanami to break free.
Only the boldest may manage to win the game – that is, if they don’t come across the evil witch thrice!

—description from the publisher

In the Kanyito universe, Kanyitos are creatures which control feelings through the use of color.

The evil Coloursnatching Witch, Kuroi Majo, has decided to kidnap them to make the world devoid of color and positive feelings. Marahuero, the witch’s cat, has decided to aid you in rescuing them.

To set a Kanyito free, you’ll need to find amongst the cards an amulet, a flower and a Kanyito of the same color.
Some of the Kanyitos have been transformed into Kanyikats, Kanyito cats, for which you’ll have to find a jewel and a kokeshi-doll instead.

The evil Witch will be chasing you, hidden in the deck. If you come across her three times, she’ll banish you from the castle!

Issue game in Command Magazine Japan #146

The Battle of Guandu was fought between the warlords Cao Cao and Yuan Shao in 200 AD in the late Eastern Han dynasty. Cao Cao's decisive victory against Yuan Shao's numerically superior forces marked the turning point in their war. The victory was also the point at which Cao Cao became the dominant power in northern China, leading to its eventual unification and the establishment of the state of Cao Wei in the Three Kingdoms period.

Players set out to collect all seven items that make up the four unique L.O.L. Surprise! dolls. Each player starts with five cards and on their turn draw two cards. On their turn they can play up to three cards by creating sets of the unique L.O.L. Surprise! dolls or play action cards like Go Shopping!, which allows the players to draw 2 additional cards from the pile. Additionally players can try to make a set of seven Secret Message cards, and upon succeeding they can discard the set to search the draw pile for any card they need. First player to complete one doll set of seven cards is the winner!

-description from designer

A Single Player Survival Game

—description from the introduction

Escape from Castle Iggur was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest.  The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The solitaire player moves up through a seven-level dungeon, from the lowest level to the top level, facing a challenge or gaining a reward on each level.  Each challenge presents a numeric rating that must be beaten by a modified die roll.  Each reward provides a bonus to subsequent die rolls.  Points are gained for each challenge defeated.

The player loses when they fail to beat a challenge, or wins when they escape the dungeon.  Game points may be compared to other game plays to determine relative success.

—user summary

Join the Reform Club, take the challenge to set the world around!
Reforma Club, inspired by the English gentleman Phileas Fogg, decides to play the bet, in which each member will have to travel around the world before the expiration of eighty days. To travel almost 24,000 miles in such a short time, you need to prepare yourself: buy a train ticket, hire an elephant, and sometimes walk a few hundred miles on foot. It is not easy, because you can spend only £135 pounds for your trip. This is not the end of surprises! You also have to watch out for the other members of the Club because they do not always play fair; dangerous pirates or locals can prevent you from traveling, and the derailment of the train will significantly delay your journey.
Win a race by planning a trip and anticipating the moves of your rivals!
Board game inspired by J. Verne's novel "Around The World In Eighty Days".

—description from the publisher (translated)

DoÅ‚Ä…cz do Klubu Reforma, podejmij wyzwanie i wyrusz w podróÅ¼ dookoÅ‚a Å›wiata!

Klub Reforma, zainspirowany wyczynami angielskiego dÅ¼entelmena Phileasa Fogga, postanawia odtworzyÄ‡ zakÅ‚ad, w którym kaÅ¼dy z czÅ‚onków bÄ™dzie musiaÅ‚ odbyÄ‡ podróÅ¼ dookoÅ‚a Å›wiata przed upÅ‚ywem osiemdziesiÄ™ciu dni. Aby przebyÄ‡ prawie 24 tysiÄ…ce mil w tak krótkim czasie, naleÅ¼y odpowiednio siÄ™ przygotowaÄ‡: kupiÄ‡ bilet na pociÄ…g, wynajÄ…Ä‡ sÅ‚onia, a czasami przejÅ›Ä‡ kilkaset mil pieszo. Nie jest Å‚atwo, bo na poczÄ…tku swojej podróÅ¼y masz w kieszeni tylko 135 funtów oraz bilet na lot balonem. To nie koniec niespodzianek! Musisz takÅ¼e uwaÅ¼aÄ‡ na pozostaÅ‚ych czÅ‚onków Klubu, poniewaÅ¼ nie zawsze grajÄ… fair; groÅºni piraci lub tubylcy mogÄ… przeszkodziÄ‡ Ci w podróÅ¼y, a wykolejenie pociÄ…gu znacznie opóÅºni TwojÄ… wyprawÄ™.

Wygraj wyÅ›cig, planujÄ…c podróÅ¼ i przewidujÄ…c ruchy swoich rywali!

Gra planszowa inspirowana powieÅ›ciÄ… J. Verne’a „W 80 dni dookoÅ‚a Å›wiata”.

—description from the publisher

Congratulations! You all have achieved the dream, you have a farm.  The world is nothing but possibility, at least for this next year.

The game takes place over 4 seasons: spring, summer, fall, and winter, with each season having 9 days.

—description from the introduction

Take Root was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest.  The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The game is played over four turns with each turn containing nine phases.  Players may choose and activity for each phase with an outcome determined by die roll.  During play, players accumulate an in-game currency (coins) and resources (seeds and harvested vegetables).  Points accumulate through play.  At the end of the game, each player puts together a "festival display" of harvested vegetables and the winning display scores points.  A few other end-of-game categories also score points.  The player with the most accumulated points is the winner.

—user summary

Wiggling in place, you tried to roll off the bed as usual, but nothing happened.

There is no bed.

There is no "you".

The vast greyness up ahead seems like the only possible way of escape.

Your body twitches as the high-pitch Russian folk music fills your two-dimensional senses, driving you mad.

What will you do?

—description from the introduction

Help! I'm a Tetra Block! was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest.  The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The game is a simple adaptation of Tetris (1984) into a paper-and-pencil, tabletop game.  Players alternate rolling a die to determine their piece configuration, and then placing that piece on the board.  Points are scored when blocks are played so they touch the top row of the playing grid.  If a line is sealed off with a gap, it is crossed off from play.  Play continues until no more legal moves are possible, at which point the player with the most points wins.

—user summary

Humphrey the Humpalump has lost his legs. To help him find his legs, players have to roll the ball along his back.  If they all lands on an empty slot you can add one of your legs.  The first player to get all their legs on Humphrey wins the game.  Humpalump, the fast fun game for all ages!

—user summary

çœŸè¨€ã‚«ãƒ«ã‚¿ (Shingon Karuta) is a Japanese card game of Karuta, using Buddhist mantras (Shingon) and artwork.

In a karuta game, players try to snatch the matching card from the other player's tableau, or protect their own card by covering it first. Typically, a separate player acts as a Reader by reading out loud from a separate deck. Players then deduce from what is read which card on display is the target, and move swiftly.

In this game of Shingon Karuta, the designer aimed to improve the education of Buddhist iconography. There is a deck of Bodhisattva cards and a deck of Shingon cards.  A Bodhiattva is a person on the path to Buddhahood, and such people are widely depicted in temple artwork, in sculpture and painting. Shingon Buddhism is one of the main schools in Japan, and the Shingon deck has sections of mantras that relate to specific Bodhisattva images.

As the Shingon card is read out, each player tries to identify the matching Bodhisattva card and snatch it or keep it.

The game was originally published in 2017, but revised in 2019 to unify the artwork to one style. The designer realised that players could simply learn the deck by the different style of artworks, and not by learning the actual Bodhisattvas. By making all the art unified, the game becomes much harder.

In 2018, the designer published an explansion set of 10 more Bodhisattva cards and 10 matching Shingon cards. Players could just play with this expansion set alone. This deck was integrated into the 2019 edition too.

—user summary

Up & Across is a two-player, abstract strategy board game on a 7×7 board.
Each player has a choice out of 2 actions. Move 2 towers or move your wizards.

Aim of the game is to bring your wizards to the other side of the board ending on your own towers. 
Wizards are only allowed to be moved one step up or one step down on the towers.
Towers with wizards on them can not be moved.

—user summary

Heavy Traffic is a two-player, abstract strategy board game that represents choas in a logistic centre on a 8x8 board.

The aim of the game is to use the truck for transporting your load to a delivery point.

There are 3 starting conditions with all different pickup and delivery points.

A truck with load can move 1 step, a truck without load can move 2 steps. 
Also use the trucks wisely to block the other players trucks.

The winner of the game is the player who transport the load as first to the destination.

—user summary

FIEF: France is a game of dynastic ambition in which players assume the roles of nobles in the 15th century kingdom of France. Each player strives to become the most powerful ruling force in the kingdom by gaining control of Fiefs and Bishoprics. In turn, they acquire Royal and Ecclesiastical (church) titles which give their families influence to elect the next Pope and King. Players strengthen their positions by negotiating marriage alliances between their families, setting the stage for love, treachery, and deception!

FIEF is a classic game and this edition includes a new board (FIEF France: Gameboard)!

The game board represents the Kingdom of France in the Middle Ages. Villages have square outlines that are connected by roads that allow Lord and Troop movement. The villages are grouped into eight colored background areas that represent individual Fiefs, which are domains given to Lords to preside over. Fiefs have different colored backgrounds. Each village also belongs to one of five church Bishoprics; each Bishopric is outlined with a heavy border line and is numbered between 1-5 along the edge of the board inside a Bishop's Mitre. Bishoprics include several different Fiefs' villages.

Each player controls up to four family members, comprised of male and female nobles. These family members will rise in power by gaining Royal and Ecclesiastic Titles.

In FIEF France edition, a player may attempt to gain control of all the villages in a Fief to gain the Royal Title of Baron, Earl, or Duke. For each Fief a player controls, they gain 1 VP. These Titled Lords may now take part in the election for the next King. They may even be a candidate to become King, thus bringing 1 VP and more power to the family! Other members of your family may follow the calling of the Church to gain the Ecclesiastical Titles of Bishop and then Cardinal. These titles allow you to Tithe Bishoprics, taking the Church's (i.e. "your") fair share of income from other Fief Lords! The highest goal your clerical family member can attain is to be elected Pope, bringing 1 VP and special privileges to your family!

You win the game as soon as you have 3 VPs. This is easier said than done and you may need to form alliances with other players through diplomacy and marriage to attain your goal. When one of your family members marries a noble of another family, the two of you become allied. You now win the game together with 4 VPs and cannot win alone, unless your marriage is annulled by the Pope or your spouse is "mysteriously" murdered or dies by some other foul means!

In addition to being wary of your fellow players, you draw event cards that can quickly change your destiny. Bounty Event cards are beneficial to the Player and include "Good Harvest", "Good Weather", and "Added Taxes" cards. But some cards are Disaster Cards that can randomly affect all players in specific Bishoprics. These include "The Plague", "Heavy Rain", "Famine", and "Peasant Uprising"!

Income can be increased by players imposing church tithes on their opponent's villages or taxing their own Fiefs. Players may purchase new Fief titles, improve their village incomes with mills, and fortify their cities.

Players will also need to protect their land and castles. Men-at-Arms and Knights can be purchased, as well as Archers and Bombards. If you feel that other players are not running their Fiefs as well as you can, you may try to invade their territories! But you must risk one of your family members to lead the troops into possible battle, where they might be killed or taken prisoner. If two opposing armies are in the same village square, a Battle may be initiated. The players assess the size and strength of their armies, which determine the number of Battle Dice each may roll. Each "f" rolled is a hit. Men-at-Arms are defeated with one hit, while Knights require three hits to be removed from the battle.

-description from publisher

Space Infantry Resurgence is a robust gaming system that features a unique solitaire game and has been further expanded to provide both co-op and two-player modes of play.  In Space Infantry Resurgence you command an elite squad of veteran Space Infantry soldiers taking on the daunting task of fighting against unknown alien foes, through challenging environments, using only the weapons and tools brought with you, or whatever can be scrounged along the way in order to achieve victory.

Space Infantry v2.0 rules are the latest set of guidelines and regulations for the game system written by Blackwell Hird and, Gottardo Zancani Lead Developers of Space Infantry Resurgence  Series.

These rules present the core rules for the game system. This new rule book has been designed to place all the rules in one book, making playing the game is easier and faster than ever.

—description from the publisher

Strategic stacking leads to precarious peaks! In Pinnacle, players take turns stacking wooden blocks of various shapes to create a perilous pile of laughter and risk-taking fun. If the shapes fall, the game ends! Ideal for players of any age who love a tactile and fun experience.

—description from the publisher

Show of Force (SOF) is a war themed competitive card game for players of all experience levels. SOF mixes the fun-for-everyone aspect of a party game, with the strategic gameplay of a trading card game.

To win you must kill your opponents by bring their Health Points to zero. This is done with the uses of 5 card types: Attack cards to do damage; Benefit cards to gain Health points; Utility cards to gain an edge; and Instant cards to be played any time for combos and defensives. Event cards are the 5th type and are randomly chosen and scattered throughout the main deck. When drawn they can be good or bad for players.

Strategy is very important because you can only play 1 card per turn, but at any moment an Event card can still ruin you plans. Gameplay types include free-for-all and team play, giving plenty of variety to a 88 card game.

—description from the designer

Runes & Regulations is a 2-4 player strategic card game that combines the aggressiveness of a horde of dragons with the passive-aggressiveness of a suburban unicorn.

Immerse yourself in this world of magic and the mundane by summoning mythical pets and casting powerful spells, all within the comfort of your own home.

Goal:  Collect 5 Mythical Creatures on your lawn to win.

To do this, you will draw cards from the main deck and add them to your hand.  Then use the cards to:


     Cast Powerful Spells
     Summon Fantastical Creatures
     Activate Enchanted Runes
     Follow HOA Regulations


You can hex a neighbors creatures, destroy them or even steal them away.

In Blutube - chi porta l'acqua in casa ("Who bring water in houses") players must compete in order to construct the most efficient city.
This game is a promo collaboration between the water provider GEAL, the City of Lucca, Lucca Crea srl and Ludoteca Lucchese.
The game was made with the support of Red Glove developers.

The game is played on a grid surrounded by bullding tiles. At his turn, each player may place tiles on the grid in order to build a pipe network and bring water to buildings. The buildings may be upgraded from a not sustenaible to a susteinable version: the player that upgrades a building scores points if the pipe network reaches that building.

A game involving action and speed. Ring the doorbell if you want the ball that has come out of the ball holder, be the first to complete your colour line, have a good think about if you want the ball as you will lose one of the ones you already got if you get it wrong.

Twisty Little Passages is a game book of dungeon crawl puzzle adventures, divided into story chapters that are broken down into a sequence of campaign areas or levels. Each campaign is a Euro-style puzzle with a fantasy theme and setting, which is played through solo and can also be engaged with as a group. The campaigns have a legacy feel where story, equipment, stats and game mechanics build atop one another and progress from one campaign to the next.

Each campaign area is laid out on a two-page spread, where the left page presents story and a description of enemies, equipment and special items, terrain and distinct properties of the area.  The right page displays a dungeon map and a space for tracking stats and inventory.

Carefully manage resources as you explore the dungeon and fight monsters.  Get keys to open doors, find magic elixirs to boost health, and acquire weapons and armor to improve attack and defense stats and reduce damage from future enemy encounters.  Prepare to fight a deadly boss at the end of each area to win and advance the story.

The book pages are laminated and you track your play progress, inventory and stats, and enemy encounters right on the page with a dry-erase pen.

Its rough out on the rim. It’s all you can do to put together enough scratch to keep your boat in the air and a gun out of your face.  You take what jobs you can get and don’t ask too many questions about the who or the what. Some days I feel like an inter system taxicab. The better you do, the more influence you get, and that’s worth more than nearly any of the cargo you might be hauling. Build enough of it and enough cash, and you might be able to convince the Central Authority to grant you access to the warp gate to the inner systems. Where life just might be a little bit easier. Maybe.

Protostar s a competitive SciFi Bounty Hunting Game for 1-5 players. Each turn, players pick a different rim system to jump to with their NavCom and explode through the galaxy to accumulate the most achievements to leave this all behind.

Players can route power from their ships to different systems, as well as increase their Boost which defines who gets to take their turn first, and gives more flexibility in battle.

Once players arrive, if they have the cash or the cargo, they may choose from a plethora of actions to help them achieve their goals.


     Buy Goods
     Sell Goods
     Salvage a card (to make money)
     Swap a card (to draw a new cord)
     Upgrade their ships different systems
     Complete a Bounty (to gain Achievements)
     Wipe a Bounty off the Board
     Fire on another player in their system.
     Repair their Hull
     Reload their Weapons
     Refuel their Engines


If a player is fired on and their shields are brought below 0, they lose some of their resources to the attacking player. But watch out for counter attacks. Its important do pay attention to what system your opponents might be going to, in order to either disrupt their plans, or avoid their fire.

Funny, colorful and full of happy actions. That's the way Tom and Jerry are known on TV, and so is this game. 2-4 players try to get a complete cheese with their mice - but that's not so easy. Because, as much as one tries to get on the auspicious cheeses fields - the evil teammates always push you back to where you do not want. And turning on the lucky clock usually does not help. And if you almost believe in your destination, you will be stealing another piece of your own cheese. There is only one thing: Pay back with the same coin...

—description from the publisher (translated)

"Starships battle for the survival of the universe!"

In this dexterity game, two players sit on opposite sides of a large "space wheel".  The space wheel is spun with two starship pucks on it.  The players control sliding "command modules" and try to keep the starship of their color in play while allowing the opposing starship to fall off.

Dogs of the Galaxies is a card game for people not embarrassed making funny faces, uttering weird words or barking “Woof”, “Woof”, while wagging the tail.  Players take turns drawing cards and describing the dogs in them; for example, what the dog looks like, what pranks it just finished pulling, or what trick it has up its sleeves - practically any way the player wants to describe the dog. Card drawer also mimics the facial expression of the dog described.

Others then compete to outdo each other by coming up with the weirdest names, captions or memes for the dogs described and, sometimes, the sounds the dogs make. The player with the weirdest name, or sound, wins the point(s) for the round. The first to get 10 points wins the game.

The player with the least point(s) wags his or her tail while barking “woof”, “woof” like a dog.

—description from the publisher

SLAMORAMA! is a crazy and I mean crazy wrestling card game that will engage your full mental capacity as much as it will tickle your funny bone. Two to four players can brawl in this mental slap-stick game as they pit their moves against each other. You start out by picking one of four wacky wrestlers; "Glittersaurus Wrecks", "Mountain Man Rick", "El Alacran", or "The She-E-O" with their arsenal of insane moves to take out their opponents. Whoever wins the most cards wins the game and you do that by collecting the most tricks. (Publisher Description)

Slamorama is a 2-4 player wrestling card game from Binary Cocoa! Players all play their best moves against each other to win rounds, and whoever wins the most rounds by the time the cards are gone wins the game!

How to play:
1. Each player is given a deck of 13 cards that consists of wrestling moves like punches or slaps or suplexes. 1 is the strongest "move" card, while 7 is the weakest.

2. Players then count to three and throw down what they think will be the strongest move, and whoever that is wins the round! On a tie players throw down an additional card until someone finally wins. No one wins the round if the tie occurs on the last round.

3. Rounds go until all players decks are empty, and whoever wins the most rounds wins!

Special Features:
1. Each wrestler has a signature move that fits their persona. For example. Mountain Man Rick's Special move is the Salmon Slam. He literally picks people up and swings them around like a bear on the Snake River. Glittersaurus Wrecks special move is the rise and shine. She will lift you up just to bring you down. Very down.

2. The game allows for future expansions that will provide more wrestlers! We are planning on calling this first edition the "Red Deck", and (pending successful funding) we will be coming out with a "Green Deck". The Green Deck will have all new wrestlers so that you can combine decks and have up to 8 players in a game.

Alternate Game Modes:
In a standard game of Slamorama each player gets a deck of 13 cards and can have 4 in their hand that they can look at. Each full deck of Slamorama comes with two additional gameplay modes that include the following:

Full Deck Mode - Where you have all 13 cards in your hand and can look at them. Saves time from having to draw cards. Gives more "tactical advantage".

Tag Team Mode - Players choose a partner and play their cards together against opponents to win rounds! They cannot look at or tell each other what they are going to throw down however. Fun with bigger groups!

Game Contents:
52 cards (13 for each wrestler)

3 rule cards (each with a unique way of playing the game)

1 tuck box to hold the cards.

The first player to accomplish the following four conditions wins the game: 1) Has purchased one of the four estates, 2) Does not owe money to the bank, 3) Has $5,000 in play money and 4) Has his playing piece at home on his estate.

Each player has four plastic pieces of their color. The Home Marker, a large flat piece, is placed over the player's apartment, townhouse or estate to show which is his home. One of the three long pieces is placed on the Salary Record Board, one on the Rent and Salary Board and one on the Home Marker. The Direction Cards are placed on the board face down. Each player is given $500 and someone is designated as the banker. Each player rolls the die and high player starts. Each player in turn selects an apartment or house and places the Home Marker with the long piece atop on it and pays the bank the rent or lease. each player in turn takes the long piece from atop the Home Marker and places it in the yellow circle marked " Downtown and rolls the die. If a 5 or 6 is rolled the player draws a Direction card and follows the instructions which may mean moving the piece to a specific place and paying an amount to the bank. If a 1, 2 or 4 is rolled, the player moves his playing piece in any direction along the marked street one red dot for each count. The objective is to get the playing piece back to the Home Marker to increase salary. Salaries are collected to amass the funds to purchase the estate and liquidate bank debts.

—user summary

Today, fame can come swiftly on the heels of a Top Twenty record, but there was a time when musicians had to prove themselves to other musicians in cutting sessions, jamming through the nights.

You are one of the, hard working, hot playing, jazz musicians, the cool cats, playing on the street corner, plinking in the piano bar, playing at that jazz café, singing in the studio, jamming at the club, drumming away that solo performance, on the stage, in the music hall, cutting sessions and winning the nights.

Jazz Nights is the 54 cards jazz-themed card game, where you stack cards and make patterns. You stack the cards at a personal tableau, which score you points at the end of sessions. The player with the highest point total of a session cuts the session. Be the first to cut three sessions and win the whole game.

Now it ain't the melody and it ain't the music, there is something else that makes the cuts complete. Gather your ensemble, choose the best location, gather the crowd, do that solo. Do the best performance at the right place. Activate your performers. Look for sets of treys. Give that rhythm everything, everything you got doo aah, dooo ah, doo ah, doo aaaah …

Gameplay

Each session one at the time, beginning with the player to the left of the dealer the players will place cards face up in front of them. You are building your own tableau of the jazz night for the current session. This tableau of stacked cards will at the end of this session be how you score. You must stack the cards as you play, cover parts of cards lain or the card you are placing. You may slide the new card under previous lain cards.

You score, by forming matched sets consisting of groups of three or more of a kind, of items, numbers, locations and musicians, or by building ensembles of three or more different musicians, or by building up a scoring crowd with sequences of coloured squares of your highest ranking location.

—description from the designer

Counter Attack is a football (soccer) strategy game which lasts for 90 minutes. The two players ('managers') each control a team of 11 players. Every player has a unique set of skills that the managers try to best utilise during play. Managers control how the players move, pass, dribble, tackle and shoot.

Duels between players on the pitch - whether tackles, shots or headers - are determined by a combination of the unique player skills plus a dice roll. During movement phases, a sand timer is used to keep the pace of the game up.

Counter Attack features everything you'd expect in a game of football, from corners to free kicks, penalties to red cards and injuries.

—description from the designer

Flip Words is a two-player game that is played on a crossword grid, much like Scrabble. One player uses the yellow side of the tiles; the other player uses the white side. Players take turns adding words to the board in Scrabble fashion. Whenever the active player adds to an opponent's word, the active player flips the tiles in that word to his color. When all the tiles have been played, the player with the most tiles on the board in his color wins.

This is an educational game that features a deck of cards with musical notes and intervals. Instructions are included for riffs on children's games such as Go Fish! and Egyptian Rat Screw. For instance, in GO! Chromatic (the Go Fish! variant) players take turns asking the other players for matching cards, e.g., C# will match a Dflat.

A trick-taking game based upon Philip Zimbardo's 1971 Stanford Prison Experiment.  The games' cards represent inmates, guards, warnings resulting from audits of the experiment, and the guards' "curriculum".

Cards played to the trick may affect an inmates ego or body.  At the end of a round it is possible for an inmates' ego to reach 0, meaning their "education" is complete.  If an inmates body reaches 0, they are considered to have died and an audit is initiated.  Warnings will be issued for various curriculum cards which were played.

At the end of the game, the winner will be the player who scored the most points by completing the "education" of inmates.

—user summary

The absurdly funny game of ridiculous charts!

If you like bizarre charts, goofy card games, and want a fresh game for your next party night, give Charty Party a try!

How to play?


     Every player draw 7 cards
     All the players choose a judge from themselves, who will draw a chart card.
     Everyone play a card by passing it face-down to the judge. Choose the funniest card which fits with the chart card.
     The judge chooses the funniest card related to the chart card, giving one point to the owner of the card. 


You can play the number of rounds you want. At the end, the player with more points win the game!

—description from the designer

NIWI is similar in scoring to the game "The First 5,000" but it involves movement on a game board where a player may land their piece on a space occupied by an opponent's piece sending the opponent's piece backward on the board and reducing the opponent's score.

The object of the game is to achieve the highest score over 5,000 by throwing scoring combinations of six dice. Players move playing pieces counter-clockwise around the numbered board to record their score. The scoring dice are: a 5 equals 50 points, a 1 equals 100 points, any 3 of a kind equals 100 times the 3-of-a-kind number. A roll of six consecutively numbered dice (a straight) on one roll equals 1500 points. A minimum of 500 points in a turn is required to get on the board. A minimum of 300 points in a turn is required to advance on the board. As long as a player rolls at least one scoring die, the player may choose to roll again to try to increase their score for that turn. The scoring dice are set aside and the non-scoring dice are picked up and rolled again. Any roll with no scoring dice ends the player's turn and no points are scored. A player may end their turn after any scoring roll and keep the points accumulated for that turn with one exception. If all six dice are scoring dice either in one roll or in a combination of rolls, the player must roll again. After the first player has scored 5000 points the other players have one last chance to outscore that player. The highest score over 5000 wins.

A player may NIWI an opponent by rolling a score which lands them on the same space as an opponent in front of them. That opponent must then retreat their piece to the previous NIWI corner of the board and their point count is reduced to that of the first scoring space preceding that NIWI corner. Also, the opponent must roll a minimum of 500 points to proceed on the board their next turn.

—user summary

An abstract game for 2-4 players where the players move a block through a hex-lattice collecting different letters of the English alphabet.  The collected letters are placed on the player's "Alphabetboard" and players earn points for collecting consecutive letters.

The @ piece acts as a wild card, N and Z have some special interactions based upon their visual similarity, and some vertices let a player teleport the pawn.

—user summary

Partán is a game of throwing dice and advancing squares, with a mechanics of interaction between the tiles that makes them "push" each other and pass to another player.

The goal is to put 5 tokens in the final tile. Initially, we have 8 tokens in the initial tile. We can only move the tokens that are in our lane. When we move a token, if the adjacent tiles have another token, it is "pushed" by ours, being able to change lanes (and thus passing to another player) or exit the board. Some tiles give us special actions (roll again, move forward or backward), and all the pushed tokens also activate those actions.

—user summary

Does everyone lay down the card that belongs to the opened symbol? 
Is someone bluffing ?
In that case hit the bell and check the last card...  Are you bluffing then you collect all the cards

He who loses all his cards first wins!

—description from the publisher (translated)

The stock market draws in investors with dreams of wealth and success — but it often spits them back out with empty pockets. Do you have what it takes to turn a profit?

Bull Rally is a simple, real-time trading game that captures many of the basic concepts and emotions of the stock market.

Over ten trading days, players buy and sell stocks in real time, then update each stock's price on the stock chart based on supply and demand, news reports, and other market conditions. Holding the right stocks at the right time will also earn dividends. The player who earns the most money wins — but anyone who earns a profit is a successful trader!

—description from the designer

ãƒ•ãƒ©ã‚¯ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ï½¥ãƒãƒ¼ã‚«ãƒ¼ (Fraction Poker) is a card game where players use a deck of cards with fractions on them (e.g. 1/2, 5/9, 5/3) to form integers.

Players start with a hand of cards and on their turn will select one from a pool face up on the table.  When a player can form an integer with the cards in their hand, they play the cards and earn points equal to the integer formed multiplied by the number of cards used.

The victory point chips show divisions of eighths on them, and players can earn additional points through combining these fractional points into further integers. (e.g. 2 points and 6 points can be viewed as 2/8 and 6/8 and together make 8/8, so an additional point is earned.)  The game ends when the victory chips or cards are gone, and the player with the most points wins.

Your village has been overrun by savage werewolves, which are represented by the number on each of the cards that make up your village. To get rid of these fanged fiends faster than the neighboring villages, use your residents' special abilities and your powerful secret weapon: a silver amulet.

Call for a vote when you think you have the fewest werewolves, but be careful; everyone else gets one more turn to save their own village first...

Silver is a fast and engaging traditional card game with a werewolf twist! Everyone starts the game with five face-down cards, with everyone being able to see two cards of their choice. Cards are numbered 0-13, with the number showing how many werewolves the character on that card attracts, and each character (number) has a different special power.

On a turn, you draw the top card of the deck or discard pile, then either discard it to use the power of the card (but only if it came from the deck), discard it without using the power (ditto), or replace one or more of your face-down cards with this card; you can replace multiple cards only if they bear the same number, and you must reveal the cards to prove this, being penalized if you're wrong.

Silver can be played as a standalone game or combined with Silver Bullet or other Silver decks. Each version of the game has different card abilities.

A two-player abstract strategy game where the goal is to move your pawn to the other player's starting row.  Cubes with arrows act as obstacles.

On a player's turn they may either move their pawn orthogonally once space (including backwards); place a cube onto the board (with restrictions on the placement of the arrow); or move a cube that is present and rotate it.
